cards.title: Calcio Storico / The most brutal sport on earth
cards.rawTitle: The most brutal sport on earth

item.title: The Calcio Storico, the most brutal sport on earth
item.trailText: The Calcio Storico – ‘historic football’ – is an ancient form of football from the 16th century, which originated from the ancient roman ‘harpastum’, and is played in teams of 27, using both feet and hands. Sucker-punches and kicks to the head are prohibited but headbutting, punching, elbowing, and choking are all allowed
item.standFirst: The Calcio Storico – ‘historic football’ – is an ancient form of football from the 16th century, which originated from the ancient roman ‘harpastum’, and is played in teams of 27, using both feet and hands. Sucker-punches and kicks to the head are prohibited but headbutting, punching, elbowing, and choking are all allowed

displayImages.caption: Players from the Santo Spirito Bianchi team prepare for the final of the Calcio Storico in Florence, Italy. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Players from the Santo Spirito Bianchi team prepare for the final of the Calcio Storico in Florence, Italy.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Players from the Santo Spirito Bianchi team prepare for the final of the Calcio Storico in Florence, Italy.

displayImages.caption: Men in traditional dress march through the city before the final match between Santo Spirito Bianchi and San Giovanni Verdi. The official rules were written in 1580 by Giovanni de Bardi, a count from Florence. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Men in traditional dress march through the city before the final match between Santo Spirito Bianchi and San Giovanni Verdi. The official rules were written in 1580 by Giovanni de Bardi, a count from Florence.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Men in traditional dress march through the city before the final match between Santo Spirito Bianchi and San Giovanni Verdi. The official rules were written in 1580 by Giovanni de Bardi, a count from Florence.

displayImages.caption: The players and officials enter Santa Croce square for the final which is played on a field of sand with 27 players on each side. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: The players and officials enter Santa Croce square for the final which is played on a field of sand with 27 players on each side.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The players and officials enter Santa Croce square for the final which is played on a field of sand with 27 players on each side.

displayImages.caption: The Santo Spirito Bianchi players bond before the start of the for the final which lasts for 50 minutes. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Santo Spirito Bianchi players bond before the start of the for the final which lasts for 50 minutes.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Santo Spirito Bianchi players bond before the start of the for the final which lasts for 50 minutes.

displayImages.caption: Cannon fire signals the start of the match. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Cannon fire signals the start of the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Cannon fire signals the start of the match.

displayImages.caption: Players fight for possession of the ball. Goals can be scored by throwing the ball over narrow slits at each end. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Players fight for possession of the ball. Goals can be scored by throwing the ball over narrow slits at each end.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Players fight for possession of the ball. Goals can be scored by throwing the ball over narrow slits at each end.

displayImages.caption: A referee and six linesmen control the game along with an off-field judge. The referee is deemed master of the field. Photograph: Vincenzo Pinto/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: A referee and six linesmen control the game along with an off-field judge. The referee is deemed master of the field.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A referee and six linesmen control the game along with an off-field judge. The referee is deemed master of the field.

displayImages.caption: The match is played for 50 minutes without interruption even if players receive injuries and are stretchered off the pitch. No substitutions are permitted. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The match is played for 50 minutes without interruption even if players receive injuries and are stretchered off the pitch. No substitutions are permitted.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The match is played for 50 minutes without interruption even if players receive injuries and are stretchered off the pitch. No substitutions are permitted.

displayImages.caption: Fans watch the brutal action from houses surrounding the Santa Croce square. Photograph: Justin Setterfield/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fans watch the brutal action from houses surrounding the Santa Croce square.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fans watch the brutal action from houses surrounding the Santa Croce square.

displayImages.caption: Martial arts techniques are permitted but it is prohibited for more than one player to attack an opponent. Any violation can lead to expulsion from the match. Photograph: Vincenzo Pinto/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: Martial arts techniques are permitted but It is prohibited for more than one player to attack an opponent. Any violation can lead to expulsion from the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Martial arts techniques are permitted but it is prohibited for more than one player to attack an opponent. Any violation can lead to expulsion from the match.

displayImages.caption: In the 17th century, enthusiasm for the Calcio Storico waned but it was revived in 1930 with the final scheduled each year on the feast day of the city’s patron saint, St John the Baptist. Photograph: Vincenzo Pinto/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: In the 17th century, enthusiasm for the Calcio Storic waned but it was revived in 1930 with the final scheduled each year on the feast day of the city’s patron saint, St John the Baptist.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In the 17th century, enthusiasm for the Calcio Storico waned but it was revived in 1930 with the final scheduled each year on the feast day of the city’s patron saint, St John the Baptist.

displayImages.caption: In 1574, when Henry III of France was staying in Venice, a fight was staged in his honour. He said that the event was ‘too small to be a real war and too cruel to be a game’. Photograph: Vincenzo Pinto/AFP/Getty
displayImages.altText: In 1574, when Henry III of France was staying in Venice, a fight was staged in his honour. He said that the event was ‘too small to be a real war and too cruel to be a game’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In 1574, when Henry III of France was staying in Venice, a fight was staged in his honour. He said that the event was ‘too small to be a real war and too cruel to be a game’.

displayImages.caption: In 2007, city officials handed out a one-year ban to the Calcio Storico after a brawl that saw 50 players taken to court. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters

item.title: Memory Lane: footballers on holiday
item.trailText: June is a time when footballers traditionally have a bit of a break before pre-season training. With some of today’s players using the interlude as an oppportunity to have a lie down in the street, we thought we would have a rummage through the archives to see what the footballers of yesteryear got up to on their downtime
item.standFirst: June is a time when footballers traditionally have a bit of a break before pre-season training. With some of today’s players using the interlude as an oppportunity to have a lie down in the street, we thought we would have a rummage through the archives to see what the footballers of yesteryear got up to on their downtime

displayImages.caption: Derby County players on holiday in Majorca celebrate after learning that they have won the 1971-72 league title. The players were able to go on a short break after completing all their fixtures early, compared to several other clubs, including Liverpool and Leeds United, who could not catch Derby’s points tally Photograph: Millow/Mirrorpix

cards.title: Motorcycle chase in Brazil ends with police officer shooting teens
cards.rawTitle: Motorcycle chase in Brazil ends with police officer shooting teens

item.title: Motorcycle chase in Brazil ends with police officer shooting teens
item.trailText: Brazilian police officer is caught on camera shooting at two teenage suspects following a high-speed chase through the streets of São Paulo
item.standFirst:
A Brazilian police officer is caught on camera shooting at two teenage suspects following a high-speed chase through the streets of São Paulo. The footage, which was broadcast live, shows the military police officer firing at the two teens, aged 16 and 17, after they crash a stolen motorbike. Both teenagers were wounded in the incident and the officer has been arrested

Warning: Some viewers may find the footage in this video disturbing

item.title: Damon Albarn's wonder.land: watch an exclusive trailer for the new musical based on Lewis Carroll story
item.trailText: wonder.land is a new musical inspired by Alice in Wonderland, with a score by Damon Albarn. Catch it at Manchester international festival, then at London's National Theatre from November
item.standFirst: wonder.land is a new musical inspired by Alice in Wonderland. It has music by Damon Albarn, lyrics by Moira Buffini and is directed by National Theatre's Rufus Norris. In the show, Lewis Carroll's fantasy world becomes an online game, to which Aly, who is bullied at school and unhappy at home, escapes. However, some of the people she meets online – Dum, Dee, the Cheshire Cat and Red Queen – seem curiously familiar. wonder.land debuts at Manchester international festival from 29 June to 12 July, then plays at National in London from 27 November.

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Wonderland trailer Photograph: guardian.co.uk

item.title: The week in wildlife
item.trailText: Wood warblers, bear cubs and Bactrian camels feature in this week’s pick of images from the natural world
item.standFirst: Wood warblers, bear cubs and Bactrian camels feature in this week’s pick of images from the natural world

displayImages.caption: Colorado columbines flourish amid fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado. Photograph: Larry Clouse/Corbis
displayImages.altText: 23 Jun 2015, Crested Butte, Colorado, USA --- Colorado columbines flourish amidst fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Colorado columbines flourish amid fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado.

displayImages.caption: Protected vicunas in the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras national reserve, Peru. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru’s government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species. Photograph: Sebastian Casta eda/AP
displayImages.altText: Protected vicunas are silhouetted against a semi-cloudy, blue sky, overlooking the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras National Reserve, Peru, Wednesday, June 24, 2015. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru's government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Protected vicunas in the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras national reserve, Peru. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru’s government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species.

displayImages.caption: Young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national ‘Chaccu’, or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras national reserve, in Ayacucho, Peru. In the roundup, Vicunas are captured, shorn and released as an expression of indigenous culture and to mark the triumph of an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals. Photograph: Sebastian Casta eda/AP
displayImages.altText: Two young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national "Chaccu," or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras National Reserve, in the Peruvian state of Ayacucho, Wednesday, June 24, 2015. The annual roundup in which vicunas are captured, shorn and released is both an expression of indigenous culture and a triumph for an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national ‘Chaccu’, or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras national reserve, in Ayacucho, Peru. In the roundup, Vicunas are captured, shorn and released as an expression of indigenous culture and to mark the triumph of an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals.

displayImages.caption: Butterflies on flowers, Balaton, Hungary. Photograph: REX Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Butterflies and flowers, Wildlife of Balaton, Hungary - 19 Jun 2015
displayImages.cleanCaption: Butterflies on flowers, Balaton, Hungary.

displayImages.caption: Wood warbler chicks sit among maple leaves after leaving their nest in Moscow park, Russia. Photograph: Victor Tyakht/Alamy
displayImages.altText: Two Wood Warbler chicks among maple leaves after leaving the nest, Moscow park, Russia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Wood warbler chicks sit among maple leaves after leaving their nest in Moscow park, Russia.

displayImages.caption: Roe deer hiding in the grass, Burley-in-Wharfedale, Ilkley, west Yorkshire, England. Photograph: Rebecca Cole /Alamy
displayImages.altText: EWBM8Y Roe deer hiding quietly in the grass, Burley-in-Wharfedale, Ilkley, West Yorkshire, England, UK, 22 June 2015
displayImages.cleanCaption: Roe deer hiding in the grass, Burley-in-Wharfedale, Ilkley, west Yorkshire, England.

displayImages.caption: A naked carp (Gymnocypris przewalskii) leaps out of water in the Shaliu river around Qinghai Lake, northwest China’s Qinghai province. Naked carps are a kind of rare carps and many migrate to the river during the spawning season. Photograph: Wu Gang/Corbis
displayImages.altText: A naked carp leaps over the Shaliu river around Qinghai Lake, northwest China's Qinghai Province, June 23, 2015. A large amount of adult migratory naked carps (Gymnocypris przewalskii), a kind of rare carps, are seen here during the spawning season.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A naked carp (Gymnocypris przewalskii) leaps out of water in the Shaliu river around Qinghai Lake, northwest China’s Qinghai province. Naked carps are a kind of rare carps and many migrate to the river during the spawning season.

displayImages.caption: An aerial shot of a white heron taking flight over exposed fish nests, that normally sit inches below the waterline in La Plata reservoir in Toa Alta, Puerto Rico. Experts say water is drying out due to El Nino, a warming of the tropical Pacific Ocean that affects global weather. Photograph: Ricardo Arduengo/AP
displayImages.altText: This June 19, 2015 aerial photo shows a white heron taking flight over revealed fish nests, normally inches below the waterline in La Plata reservoir in Toa Alta, Puerto Rico. Thanks to El Nino, a warming of the tropical Pacific Ocean that affects global weather, less rain fell to help refill Puerto Rico s La Plata reservoir, as well as La Plata river in the central island community of Naranjito. A tropical disturbance that hit the U.S. territory on Monday did not fill up those reservoirs as officials had anticipated.
displayImages.cleanCaption: An aerial shot of a white heron taking flight over exposed fish nests, that normally sit inches below the waterline in La Plata reservoir in Toa Alta, Puerto Rico. Experts say water is drying out due to El Nino, a warming of the tropical Pacific Ocean that affects global weather.

displayImages.caption: Wild macaques in Qianling Mountain on last day of Dragon Boat festival in Guiyang, Guizhou province of China.  Photograph: ChinaFotoPress/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Wild macaques in Qianling Mountain on last day of Dragon Boat Festival holiday on June 22, 2015 in Guiyang, Guizhou province of China. Dragon Boat Festival holiday continued on June 22 and visitors went on their entertainment time.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Wild macaques in Qianling Mountain on last day of Dragon Boat festival in Guiyang, Guizhou province of China.

displayImages.caption: A young wild beaver hitches a ride with its mother on the River Otter in Devon. England’s only wild beavers have had babies. Beavers were re-released in the Otter earlier this year after being captured and tested for disease. Photograph: Tom Buckley/Devon Wildlife Trust/PA
displayImages.altText: A young wild beaver (right) hitching a ride with its mother on the River Otter in Devon, June 24, 2015. England's only wild beavers have had babies, conservationists have said. The colony of beavers, which has been living wild on the river for at least three years and possibly up to a decade, was re-released on to the Otter earlier this year after being captured and tested for disease.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A young wild beaver hitches a ride with its mother on the River Otter in Devon. England’s only wild beavers have had babies. Beavers were re-released in the Otter earlier this year after being captured and tested for disease.

displayImages.caption: A Bactrian camel at Whipsnade zoo in Whipsnade, England. The camels look a little shaggy as their thick hair begins moulting off in straggly clumps to make way for their finer summer coats. Photograph: Tony Margiocchi/Barcroft Media
displayImages.altText: A Bactrian camel is seen at Whipsnade Zoo on June 21, 2015 in Whipsnade, England.   The camels look a little shaggy as their thick hair begins moulting off in straggly clumps to make way for their finer summer coats.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Bactrian camel at Whipsnade zoo in Whipsnade, England. The camels look a little shaggy as their thick hair begins moulting off in straggly clumps to make way for their finer summer coats.

displayImages.caption: Iberian lynx, Lava, takes its first steps after being released on a farm near the village of Mazarambros near Toledo, Spain, as a part of an initiative to repopulate the endangered species. Conservationists are worried that disproportionate numbers are being run down by cars. Photograph: Pierre-philippe Marcou/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Iberian lynx Lava takes its first steps after being released on a farm near the village of Mazarambros near Toledo on April 24, 2015 part of an initiative to repopulate the endangered species.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Iberian lynx, Lava, takes its first steps after being released on a farm near the village of Mazarambros near Toledo, Spain, as a part of an initiative to repopulate the endangered species. Conservationists are worried that disproportionate numbers are being run down by cars.

displayImages.caption: 40 mammalian species, from antelopes to zebras, in the African savanna in Tanzania were snapped by 225 hidden cameras, in a wildlife project by Snapshot Serengeti and Scientific Data Journal. Photograph: Snapshot Serengeti/Scientific Data Journal
displayImages.altText: Snapshot Serengeti, high-frequency annotated camera trap images of 40 mammalian species in an African savanna -
displayImages.cleanCaption: 40 mammalian species, from antelopes to zebras, in the African savanna in Tanzania were snapped by 225 hidden cameras, in a wildlife project by Snapshot Serengeti and Scientific Data Journal.

displayImages.caption: The West Pentire arable fields near Newquay, England, are exploding in a riot of red poppies and yellow corn marigolds, creating a much-needed haven for some of the most endangered wild flowers in the country. Photograph: Steven Haywood/National Trust
displayImages.altText: Cornish coast puts on summer show   Weasel’s snout, Venus’s looking glass, small-flowered catchfly…as summer unfolds one of the south west’s rarest natural spectacles comes into its own along the north Cornish coast.   Carefully managed for nature and people by the National Trust, the West Pentire arable fields near Newquay are exploding in a riot of red poppies and yellow corn marigolds – but also creating a much-needed haven for some of the most endangered wild flowers in the country.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The West Pentire arable fields near Newquay, England, are exploding in a riot of red poppies and yellow corn marigolds, creating a much-needed haven for some of the most endangered wild flowers in the country.

displayImages.caption: Playful bear cubs lock claws in Lake Clark, Alaska, home to 98% of US’s bear population. Photograph: Greg Morgan/Barcroft Media
displayImages.altText: The playful cubs fight on June, 19, 2015, in Lake Clark, Alaska.  Playful bear cubs lock paws and show their teeth during a harmless scrap in the grass. The young animals were spotted wrestling for roughly five minutes in Lake Clark, Alaska, by amateur photographer Greg Morgan. The US state has the highest amount of brown bears in the US, and is home to roughly 98% of the country s entire population of the species.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Playful bear cubs lock claws in Lake Clark, Alaska, home to 98% of US’s bear population.

displayImages.caption: Ivory artefacts weighing a ton was confiscated by the US Fish and Wildlife Service and New York State, and displayed in Times Square in New York where it was later crushed. Antique dealer Victor Gordon of Philadelphia was sentenced to 30 months in prison and fined $157,500. Poaching of ivory is killing 96 elephants a day in Africa, experts say. Photograph: Richard Levine/Corbis
displayImages.altText: 19 Jun 2015, Manhattan, New York City, New York State, USA --- New York, United States. 19th June 2015 -- One ton of illegal ivory confiscated by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and New York State is displayed and crushed in Times Square in New York. -- The confiscated ivory was mostly obtained from an antique dealer Victor Gordon in Philadelphia who was sentenced to 30 months in prison and fines $157,500. The ivory contributes to the decimation of the elephants in Africa at the rate of 96 per day.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ivory artefacts weighing a ton was confiscated by the US Fish and Wildlife Service and New York State, and displayed in Times Square in New York where it was later crushed. Antique dealer Victor Gordon of Philadelphia was sentenced to 30 months in prison and fined $157,500. Poaching of ivory is killing 96 elephants a day in Africa, experts say.

displayImages.caption: My lookout spot: fox cub Hetty climbs on photographer Richard Bowler near Corwen, Wales, UK. Bowler adopted the 12-week-old fox from a friend who specialised in hand-rearing animals. Photograph: Helen Thorpe/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Richard Bowler with Hetty the fox cub on his back Hetty the fox cub stands on owner, near Corwen, Wales, Britain - 18 Jun 2015  Animal photographer Richard Bowler found himself the subject of a snap for once when his fox cub pal Hetty used him as a lookout.  Trying to take a few pictures at his smallholding near Corwen, Wales, Richard became a handy high-point from which to survey the garden.  Richard adopted the twelve-week-old fox from a friend who specialises in hand-rearing animals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: My lookout spot: fox cub Hetty climbs on photographer Richard Bowler near Corwen, Wales, UK. Bowler adopted the 12-week-old fox from a friend who specialised in hand-rearing animals.

image.caption: Colorado columbines flourish amid fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado. Photograph: Larry Clouse/Corbis
image.altText: 23 Jun 2015, Crested Butte, Colorado, USA --- Colorado columbines flourish amidst fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado.
image.cleanCaption: Colorado columbines flourish amid fields of Rocky Mountain wildflowers along Scofield Pass, near Crested Butte, Colorado.

image.caption: Protected vicunas in the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras national reserve, Peru. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru’s government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species. Photograph: Sebastian Casta eda/AP
image.altText: Protected vicunas are silhouetted against a semi-cloudy, blue sky, overlooking the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras National Reserve, Peru, Wednesday, June 24, 2015. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru's government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species.
image.cleanCaption: Protected vicunas in the Andean plains on the Pampa Galeras national reserve, Peru. For centuries, hunters killed the elusive vicuna for its wool and leather rather than shear it live. The species was on the brink of extinction by 1964, when Peru’s government established the national reserve, now the principal sanctuary for the species.

image.caption: Young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national ‘Chaccu’, or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras national reserve, in Ayacucho, Peru. In the roundup, Vicunas are captured, shorn and released as an expression of indigenous culture and to mark the triumph of an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals. Photograph: Sebastian Casta eda/AP
image.altText: Two young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national "Chaccu," or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras National Reserve, in the Peruvian state of Ayacucho, Wednesday, June 24, 2015. The annual roundup in which vicunas are captured, shorn and released is both an expression of indigenous culture and a triumph for an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals.
image.cleanCaption: Young men dressed as Inca servants carry a vicuna to be sheared during the national ‘Chaccu’, or annual roundup of vicunas, in the Pampa Galeras national reserve, in Ayacucho, Peru. In the roundup, Vicunas are captured, shorn and released as an expression of indigenous culture and to mark the triumph of an international campaign to save the once-endangered animals.

cards.title: Havin' a giraffe! / Safari selfies taken by the animals
cards.rawTitle: Safari selfies taken by the animals

item.title: Havin' a giraffe! Safari selfies taken by the animals
item.trailText: Candid, cute, almost confessional: intimate images of wildlife, from antelopes to zebras, in their African savanna habitat. But can you name them all?
item.standFirst: Candid, cute, almost confessional ... these intimate wildlife shots are all thanks to Snapshot Serengeti, who hid 225 camera traps in the vast national park in Tanzania, and let everything from antelopes to zebras snap themselves in their natural savanna habitat. But can you name them all?

displayImages.caption: All pictures courtesy Snapshot Serengeti and the Scientific Data Journal
displayImages.altText: Snapshot Serengeti
displayImages.cleanCaption: All pictures courtesy Snapshot Serengeti and the Scientific Data Journal
